formalpara.para: Gαs is induced to bind GTP to generate its active form by GPCRs. RIC-8 promotes signaling, either via its Gα chaperone function or as a non-receptor activator. Gαs-GTP inactivates itself (not shown) via its slow intrinsic GTPase activity. Gαs-GTP activates the transmembrane enzyme adenylyl cyclase to generate the second messenger cyclic AMP (cAMP), which ultimately is hydrolyzed by phosphodiesterase. cAMP binds the regulatory subunits of protein kinase A (PKA), causing them to release the active subunit. PKA phosphorylation of unknown target proteins activates release of both synaptic and dense-core vesicles to increase neurotransmitter release. Solid grey arrows indicate direct physical interactions. Dashed arrow indicates a poorly understood effect. Green, proteins that promote Gαs signaling; red, proteins that inhibit Gαs signaling.
